author: Steve Schering
title: Housing Center, Dist. 97 seek to help victims of Oak Park apartment fire Oak Leaves
text:
As the victims of the Oct. 20 apartment fire in Oak Park recover from the loss of their homes, the Oak Park community is stepping up to help.
One day after the fire displaced the 29 adults and 11 children who lived in the 22-unit building, the Oak Park Regional Housing Center announced it is collecting donations to be given to those in need of assistance.
Cash donations can be made online or can be dropped off at the Housing Center at 1041 South Blvd.
"We're trying to keep it very simple," said Housing Center Executive Director Rob Breymaier. "They can drop off gift cards, checks or cash."
Breymaier said cash or gift cards are the preferred donations, as they allow each family to purchase items they need the most.
"The best thing to do is donate [online]," Breymaier said. "Sometime over the next week, we can divide that up for the 19 families that were in the building and provide some support. They know best what they're in need of and it's best to provide something as flexible as possible."
Additionally, Oak Park Elementary School District 97 is collecting donations to assist district families who lived in the apartments.

(Steve Schering) According to a message posted by the district, six families and eight students from Longfellow Elementary School and Julian Middle School were displaced by the fire.
District 97 is asking for clothing and gift card donations, and is recommending Visa or American Express gift cards as well as gift cards to Target, Kohl's, Walmart, Walgreens or CVS.
"I worked with the PTO presidents to initiate this process because so many people in the Longfellow Community had started reaching out to our PTO first thing [Wednesday] morning," said Longfellow Principal Angela Dolezal. "They were all looking for ways to help and [Julian Principal Todd Fitzgerald] and I thought it would be best to combine efforts since a couple families affected attend both schools."
Donors are encouraged to bring clothing or gift cards to Longfellow School, 715 S. Highland Ave. The items will be given to families on a regular basis or as needed in the days ahead.
"We have already received a lot of clothes, especially clothes for girls who wear size 7 and 8," Dolezal said. "If members of the community were going to continue to drop off clothes, we need more of the male items. Gift cards will continue to be a need."
